Short thread on training theology:

1. Classical bodybuilding (where emphasis is put on proportionality/form/aesthetics) is inherently Christian.

It is based on an understanding that there is a certain perfection/ideal that you strive to achieve. It's a corporal form of theosis.

2. Modern bodybuilding (where emphasis is put on pure lean mass/size) is inherently anti-Christian/Faustian.

It consists of turning your musculature into a Tower of Babel and its core idea is that there is no ceiling, no limit to reach. It is based on an atheistic worldview.
Local ones, mall shit, Bulgarian brands etc.

We can easily see that the first one is natural, while, to participate in the second one, artificial substances (trenbolone, which is literally made for horses [and is unnatural for them too of course]), purposeful dehydration, synthol and other unnatural means of deception.

Where does this put powerlifting? If we take the above in mind, the only conclusion we arrive to can be:

- Powerlifting can be seen as good only if you put a certain limit and try to achieve it instead of blindly climbing up the numbers. You can afterwards set another limit.

I recommend you to expose your naked body to the elements, for the purpose of strengthening it:

- Scorching sunlight (but protect your skin from putrid moonlight)
- Soul-melting heat, saunas followed by dips in icy water
- Heavy rains and balance-shattering wind
- Hard friction

Something that surprised me in early physique competitions was that one of the "criteria" was STATE OF SKIN

Of course, good skin could not have meant softness, but contrary - its strength, resistance, sturdiness. Your skin is your biggest organ (after the soul), take care of it!

Honestly something I really wish to indulge in in the future are chess puzzles. From an outsider perspective they seem absolutely fascinating. All the theory that goes into them, all the special "technical" pieces. It's a whole world, and all of it is deeply, deeply curious.

I suspect that chess puzzles are one of the best methods for mind training/development due to their nature of combining different methods of thought for achieving the solution - improvisation, theory, foresighting - a good government would surely include them in the curriculum.
I played it with my grandpa back in the day, boomers here love it. I love games with a randomness element personally, makes for an everexciting experience

Every other afternoon I go up to my balcony and attempt to take a picture of the beautiful clouds over my town; and every time the picture looks nothing like the skyline and I mourn the inability of our technology to capture reality. It mocks me.
